subject: Embedding e-publication code
description:
We have been asked to embed some code which will provide a link to an e-publication. It would go on this page (unless it needs to be embedded in a whole page): http://www.london2012.com/about-us/our-brand/retail-information/london-2012-retail-opportunities.php I'm not sure how this is supposed to render, so wonder if it's possible to put the code in a test page we can review?
Open publication - Free publishing - More catalogue

comments.value:
We have been asked to embed some code which will provide a link to an e-publication. It would go on this page (unless it needs to be embedded in a whole page): http://www.london2012.com/about-us/our-brand/retail-information/london-2012-retail-opportunities.php I'm not sure how this is supposed to render, so wonder if it's possible to put the code in a test page we can review?
Open publication - Free publishing - More catalogue

Hi Morag,

It looks like it's one of those PDF viewers (ah yes it's Issuu --> http://issuu.com/) 

But that viewer doesn't fit on that page, I guess we could use something like the Map template layout, but then you'd lose the left hand navigation.

Probably the nicest solution would be to get a embed that fitted that centre column (which is 460px) but then let people view it full screen (I know you can do this in Issuu's viewer, from past experience)

Ah something like this..
http://www.littlewhitelies.co.uk/the-magazine/issue-33

Or you could just link to the PDF?

Hi Jamie

Happy to lose the left hand navigation as it’s a one off page – how easy would it be to customise a template just for this?

HI Morag,

I reckon it would probably take about half a day to get everything setup and in place, see first screen grab (attached) for what ti would look like on a wide template.

Although I did a have a quick look at the Issuu (the viewer being used) docs and realised I could shrink the player/viewer to fit the central column  see second screen grab (attached).

Let me know what you'd prefer and if you want us to proceed.

Jamie
Brilliant. Reviewing this with the client – will let you know asap!

Any updates on this one?

(just doing some house cleaning!)
Tom says: by Wednesday this week, if at all possible. And wide templated preferred, if possible.

Hi Tom,

Can I just check which version you prefer, the wide (losing the left hand nav) or in the middle column, personally I think the wide is better if it doesn't need to sit in a section with other pages (and hence need the lh nav)

Jamie

I think its fine to have it in the wide template – I imagine this is easiest?

I think we need a title and text box above however – so we can offer an explanation and links elsewhere.

Thanks

Have created a page here, feel free to edit the text . move to wherever you want it to live.
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/test/licensingandretailcatalogue.php

btw. is this likely to be a one off or are you going to have more of these Issuu style PDF embedded in pages? Just wondering if it's worth doing the extra work to make it more parametrized, so you can assign different publications ( btw. it's not trivial to parametrize or else we would have just done it, it's prob. half a days work). But if you are likely to have more in future it makes sense to do it now, becasue creating a new template for every publication would be equally insane.

I actually can’t edit anything on here?

This is likely to be a one off – max one more, so I think its fine to leave it as one template.

However - I can’t see the catalogue or any editable text?

Thanks

Tom, Can I check your looking at it in edit mode, it's working fine for everyone here. 
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/test/licensingandretailcatalogue.php

Also you may not see it in preview is your browsers gest upset by https and http content (the cms forces the page to be loaded as https but the embed is loaded over http). Once published this won't be an issue as both page and embed will be served over http.

subject: Last bits to tie up with Learning Legacy
description:
NOT PROTECTIVELY MARKED Hi both, Hope you're well? Thanks once again for all your hard work and patience with the Learning Legacy website. Everyone here is delighted with it. There are now a few last things we need to do to complete the site before I leave the ODA (in December). I have outlined the final tasks below. Please can you take a look and send over a quote for this work? I think we will need a quick chat to go through all of this in detail so that I'm as clear as I can be on what we require - how about Monday? 1. Analytics - we are being harassed about measuring the number of people visiting the site, which is absolutely something we should have thought about before. What is the cost to build the capacity to measure the number of people visiting the home page? And also another cost for the home page and theme pages? This is quite urgent, so it would be great to get this set up ASAP. 2. Accessibility - there is an issue with the accessibility style sheets, as in they don't look great. AbilityNet picked up that the pages should 'render with a layout similar to the normal site, but with bigger text and more contrasting colours'. I know you've advised that doing that would mean effectively designing a new CSS layout/design purely for the accessible versions of each page - please can we get a quote for redesigning the accessible versions of the pages? 3. Flash plug-in - there is an issue with the London 2012 logo/scrolling pictures on the home page in Internet Explorer. I think this is something to do with 'flash plug-ins', as this was the error message that came up when we loaded the site in Firefox at the ICE. Please can you explore and rectify? 4. Alt text on scrolling pictures - we need the alt text to show as a yellow box when hovering over the images so that people know where they are. I think you have said this will require a component/function adding so may have cost implications. Can we get a quote for this please? 5. Archaeology navigation - in order to get the nesting right (to mirror the site map) we had to lose the top level menu when you click on 'The investigations' and 'The sites'. This is not ideal, as it simply doesn't look great. What options do we have to amend/fix this? 6. Full list of publications - The project team want us to add an option on each theme page for a full list of publications per theme (ie a list of all micro reports, case studies, champion products and research summaries for Sustainability). Can we add a link, or another box for this? Would be great to go through the options and costs for this. 7. External links page - we would like to add in External Links for each theme page. I reckon there will be around five external websites for us to link out to, per theme. Maybe this could sit under the 'related links' on the right? Also would be great to discuss options. 8. Technical Overviews - we are publishing some technical overviews of the project, which are external papers that we just need to link to. Because these are overviews of the project, and not theme-specific, are we able to add a tab at the top, which takes you to a page about the overviews? It just needs to be a page, with information about three organisations delivering the overviews. 9. Case study summaries - there are a number of case studies being published by external organisations next year that we have the summaries/abstracts for. We need these summaries to go on the website with links to the full case studies/publishers. I suggest that these go under the case studies section, or we have another 'box' for case study summaries. However, these aren't documents to upload (as with case studies), so there will be no thumbnail and no physical PDF to link to. It will just need to be a generic image, with the summary/abstract to go into the text box next to the thumbnail, and the link will take you to an external website (rather than a PDF). Hope this makes sense? The only other catch is that the links won't be available until next year! Best to talk through this one! 10. LOCOG testing of the website - Colin Miller has been continuing to test the website since we've gone live and has picked up a few 'aesthetic niggles'. I have asked him to outline what these are and will get back to you ASAP. They are not expected to be extensive and I'm hoping we can fix these in-house. Hope this all makes sense. As suggested, let's catch up early next week and then get a lump-sum for all of these changes. comments.value:
NOT PROTECTIVELY MARKED Hi both, Hope you're well? Thanks once again for all your hard work and patience with the Learning Legacy website. Everyone here is delighted with it. There are now a few last things we need to do to complete the site before I leave the ODA (in December). I have outlined the final tasks below. Please can you take a look and send over a quote for this work? I think we will need a quick chat to go through all of this in detail so that I'm as clear as I can be on what we require - how about Monday? 1. Analytics - we are being harassed about measuring the number of people visiting the site, which is absolutely something we should have thought about before. What is the cost to build the capacity to measure the number of people visiting the home page? And also another cost for the home page and theme pages? This is quite urgent, so it would be great to get this set up ASAP. 2. Accessibility - there is an issue with the accessibility style sheets, as in they don't look great. AbilityNet picked up that the pages should 'render with a layout similar to the normal site, but with bigger text and more contrasting colours'. I know you've advised that doing that would mean effectively designing a new CSS layout/design purely for the accessible versions of each page - please can we get a quote for redesigning the accessible versions of the pages? 3. Flash plug-in - there is an issue with the London 2012 logo/scrolling pictures on the home page in Internet Explorer. I think this is something to do with 'flash plug-ins', as this was the error message that came up when we loaded the site in Firefox at the ICE. Please can you explore and rectify? 4. Alt text on scrolling pictures - we need the alt text to show as a yellow box when hovering over the images so that people know where they are. I think you have said this will require a component/function adding so may have cost implications. Can we get a quote for this please? 5. Archaeology navigation - in order to get the nesting right (to mirror the site map) we had to lose the top level menu when you click on 'The investigations' and 'The sites'. This is not ideal, as it simply doesn't look great. What options do we have to amend/fix this? 6. Full list of publications - The project team want us to add an option on each theme page for a full list of publications per theme (ie a list of all micro reports, case studies, champion products and research summaries for Sustainability). Can we add a link, or another box for this? Would be great to go through the options and costs for this. 7. External links page - we would like to add in External Links for each theme page. I reckon there will be around five external websites for us to link out to, per theme. Maybe this could sit under the 'related links' on the right? Also would be great to discuss options. 8. Technical Overviews - we are publishing some technical overviews of the project, which are external papers that we just need to link to. Because these are overviews of the project, and not theme-specific, are we able to add a tab at the top, which takes you to a page about the overviews? It just needs to be a page, with information about three organisations delivering the overviews. 9. Case study summaries - there are a number of case studies being published by external organisations next year that we have the summaries/abstracts for. We need these summaries to go on the website with links to the full case studies/publishers. I suggest that these go under the case studies section, or we have another 'box' for case study summaries. However, these aren't documents to upload (as with case studies), so there will be no thumbnail and no physical PDF to link to. It will just need to be a generic image, with the summary/abstract to go into the text box next to the thumbnail, and the link will take you to an external website (rather than a PDF). Hope this makes sense? The only other catch is that the links won't be available until next year! Best to talk through this one! 10. LOCOG testing of the website - Colin Miller has been continuing to test the website since we've gone live and has picked up a few 'aesthetic niggles'. I have asked him to outline what these are and will get back to you ASAP. They are not expected to be extensive and I'm hoping we can fix these in-house. Hope this all makes sense. As suggested, let's catch up early next week and then get a lump-sum for all of these changes. I want to ensure that we are very clear from the outset and that you are paid for all the extra work you are doing. Hope you have a lovely weekend. Speak next week. 1) Accessibility issues - 1 day
The originally CSS / HTML was supplied by a 3rd party (Reading Room) Given that the site has now been constructed using those files we will need to investigate what would be retrospectively involved in us meeting all or some of Ability.net suggestions. Therefore we propose that we spend a day investigating and breaking down the work involved in meeting all of Ability.net requirements. Where possible we will simple address the issues, indeed we have already address several of the issues highlighted in Ability.net report, but some the larger issues the deliverables will simply be an estimate of work involved. We will aim to keep out recommendations sensible, in terms of costs vs the possible perfect solution if we we're starting with a blank slate.

a. Fix low hanging issues where possible
b. Supply a breakdown of work and time required to address other issues highlighted in Ability.net report (this may result in further un-costed work)

* please note, that as the site has already been built, the perfect resolution of certain ability.net issues may not be achievable by minor/medium sized "retrospective" changes and therefore could 
require very large sections of the site to be totally rewritten, we are assuming this is not a sensible route (ie. rebuilding the site is not an option) and therefore will suggest sensible compromises.

2) Add text "label" under "theme" images on home page 
Update the HTML/CSS and Javascript scroller code so that each theme image can be assigned a name, which will also hyperlink though to the relevant section.

3) Archaeology navigation
When in the 2nd level of the Archaeology navigation show the 1st level 
of Archaeology links

4) Technical overview tab
If you are happy creating a new "Technical overview" section at the root of the site in a similar manor to the "About us" section and filling it with pages (using the same templates used in the about us section).

We will add the necessary changes to
a. include an additional tab and rollovers
b. logic so this section is correctly highlighted when you are within it
c. basic help in getting the section us and running.
d. help in bulk republishing the site to include this new section

* please note, we are not proposing to create any new templates or logic (other than the tab) for this section.

5) Events tab 
Create a new “Events” tab and resize existing tabs so all fit without wrapping. Tab to be designed so we will be able to have a page for each organisation.

Lars

On the home page scroller (Learning Legacy themes) they want a text label under each image (for the name of the theme). http://learninglegacy.london2012.com/ Best leave this one in preview and lock the homepage once done.

The next ones is, my guess if  best placed to handle, are the accessibility issues (see above; in short they want it more like on www rather than running all one item after anoher). If the fixes are easy make them, anything that looks tricky make a note and leave it.

I'll deal with the the arch navigation and tabs, but may ask for your help on getting the CSS/HTML for the extra two tabs looking sweet. If you can't face accessibility issues first thing, maybe look at what needs to change to add the extra tabs. 

thanks

Jamie

subject: Events database search interface for london2012.com
description:
I know the Festival website isn't yet live .... but we need to think about the next step with the events database!

By the end of 2011 we will have a lot of additional events in the GDP database, and need to allow users to search the database and view results.

This means we need to build a front-end search and results tool within a page on london2012.com.

The key dates are:

1.       1 Dec  - web form goes live

2.       w/c 9 Jan - web search goes live

I'd be grateful for your thoughts re this, in particular:

1.       Do we need to commission search / results interface design from an agency?

2.       Feasibility of the timings above - it's basically 10 weeks but Christmas/New Year comes in the middle

3.       Feedback on how you have found the GDP web service - if you are happy with this as a viable solution for delivering the search and results

Can we catch up on this at some point this week?

Thanks!

Morag Reavley
Senior New Media Manager

Canary Wharf
London

Sorry - know you are completely snowed! But wondering if you had any thoughts on the above - do we need to commission code for this? My feeling is that the search will not be dissimilar to the Festival site (with the likely addition of a couple of other search criteria) but we also need the abilty to display events on a map (though Earthware will be doing the map rendering).

1. Agency? Probably sensible. It's not just design. There's a bit of IA, too. I imagine there are decisions to made about how to present different sets of results.
2. Feasibility? High, subject to other priorities. We have done a lot of the work already for Festival. Reusing the code on the london2012 domain and plugging in different designs is not likely to be onerous.
3. GDP? Everything seems to be working on festival (now that we have DNS sorted out). We are happy with the solution.
Good-o. And in terms of agency involvement, would it just be a case of design, or stylesheets or full html templates for search and results?
Perhaps not entire pages, because we want to fit the pages into the overall london2012 site layout, but we will want HTML fragments which we can plug into the london2012 master template structure.
Cool

description:

We will inform Kitsite when this is coming back up.

Thanks

Russ

subject: Decoupling of links to london2012 sub-domains on main site
description:
We are looking at how we can easily isolate parts of our site from the basic London2012 site in case of issues.  For example, if the shop went down or was corrupted we would want to put a page up instead of linking to shop.london2012.com to isolate it.  There are a number of areas that we would want to do this to:

Getset
Tickets
Shop
Pregames training camps
Recruitment
Mascots

comments.value:
We are looking at how we can easily isolate parts of our site from the basic London2012 site in case of issues.  For example, if the shop went down or was corrupted we would want to put a page up instead of linking to shop.london2012.com to isolate it.  There are a number of areas that we would want to do this to:

Getset
Tickets
Shop
Pregames training camps
Recruitment
Mascots
Estimate and timescale needed.

Two options (at least): == Option one We could wrap all external links in a piece of (pseudo) php: if (SHOP_DISABLED) { // output nothing } else { Shop } "SHOP_DISABLED" would be a global php variable that can be set in response to reports of problems with the shop. Pros: shop.london2012.com would receive correct HTTP_REFERER info. Cons: Need to login to staging server, or amend a php file in the cms in order to set this variable (and hence disable shop links). In either case, it's simple, but potentially dangerous. == Option two We could host "interim" pages for each external url. i.e. the links would look as follows: Shop This page would then serve a redirect to http://shop.london2012.com. If we need to decouple the shop for some reason, then we simply amend the /interim-shop-page.php page, and republish. Pros: The interim page can be configured to show a message (e.g. "the shop is currently unavailable, sorry") during downtime periods. Cons: The shop would /not/ receive correct HTTPP_REFERER info. We can discuss other options, if neither of the above is acceptable. Both of them involve scouring the template code for hard-coded links to external urls, and so could prove quite time-consuming. I'm estimating 5 days here (for everything - technical solution, template amendments, testing, deployment) but it might be higher, depending on the solution we choose.

Russ says that the priority is for it to be easy to make changes, so that locog staff can update the links without our assistance, similar to the existing get-involved/volunteer/atos-returning-user-redirect.php. So, Option two is the preferred route.

Ok, well ... I estimate 5 days.
Can I just (double) confirm that everyone is ok with the referrer data being lost?
By this, I mean that (for example) /all/ hits on shop.london2012.com will appear to have come from "http://www.london2012.com/redirect/shop.php". Thus meaning that shop.london2012.com cannot do any analytics on which www.london2012.com pages generate them the most traffic.

There is one possible alternative, but it would have to be okayed by the SEO people first:
Lets say "http://www.london2012.com/some-page.php" wants to link to "http://shop.london2012.com/".
Instead of using a dedicated proxy page, we could - instead - link to itself, but with a querystring param added:
  http://www.london2012.com/some-page.php?redir=shop
This page would then notice the "redir=shop" and serve a 302 (or 303?) to send the user to: http://shop.london2012.com/. The shop would thus still see the referrer info which - I presume - is of some commercial value to you and them.

To do it this way would probably add another day to the task - although it /might/ still come in at 5 days.

Kieran

I agree – need to be sure that we don’t foul up the analytics on this – good catch.

Russ

Have set this to pending.
If authorized, I will set it back to "Open" and complete the work.
just spoke to Russ about this, too. He said he will get back to us later in the month.

subject: Facebook Sharing of London2012.com
description:
We discovered yesterday that if we post a link to any page of the London2012.com website on Facebook no images are found to use as thumbnails.  We've checked with other sites and this seems to be working fine. This will be a significant problem when we're updating our social media channels - have any changes been made that might prevent Facebook finding these images?

A couple of things to note:
1. The homepage is the exception - Facebook is able to scrape images from here.
2. We've tested from numerous computers both on and off the LOCOG network.

[cid:image001.png@01CC0010.F7788810]
Regards,
Andy

Andy, can you give some examples on facebook with URLs of posts that are displaying this problem?

No, as we’ve not posted anything in the last few days. But you can try yourself just by going to any page on the website and using the share on Facebook link at the bottom, or pasting the URL directly into Facebook.

The one I found it with was:
http://www.london2012.com/games/torch-relays/index.php

As far as I can tell if affects most pages but not the home page. These randomly selected ones don’t work:
http://www.london2012.com/making-it-happen/sustainability/index.php
http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/inspire-programme/index.php
http://www.london2012.com/visiting/getting-to-the-games/index.php

That said, I’ve just found that this one does:
http://www.london2012.com/get-involved/upcoming-events/index.php

Curious.

It appears that the Facebook share interface is now deprecated in favour of their 'Like" button: http://developers.facebook.com/docs/reference/plugins/like/

The upshot is that behaviour of http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php cannot be guaranteed and there appears to be no way of forcing page images to load.

We may want to consider changing our page links to use the new interface.

I think this is one for Finn to drive, but yes, I believe we will need to update the share interface.

The article here is interesting and suggests a few things to try:
http://ansonalex.com/troubleshooting/fix-articles-linked-on-facebook-dont-display-thumbnails-images/

Also, I’ve noticed that the Facebook lint checker fails to find images on most of our pages – in particular (for the pages I’ve tried) shop product images and supporter logos in PNG format.

Finn – what priority is this for you?
It certainly would be nice to get this working properly. I guess it depends on how much work this is for you Danny. I’d like you to find that out please though so we can make a call on it.

Probably the correct way to solve this issue is to use Facebook's Open Graph Protocol: http://developers.facebook.com/docs/opengraph/ 

This would not mean changing the facebook code at all, but it would mean adding code to the header of the page.

We could probably add a single "<meta property="og:image" content="http://www.london2012.com/some-image.jpg"/>" to the top of all pages. 

Alternatively, we could probably allow the content of this tag to be specified page by page, but this would add an extra layer of editorial effort and require a bit of coding.

The simplest approach would be a single new metatag to be added to all pages which could possibly be done in under a day (almost all of which would be confirming this approach will work, testing and deployment, rather than actual development).

Other approaches would take more time, depending on what we actually ended up doing.

Hi Tom,

I think these are already in these pages?

Also the 'email confirmation' page (https://www.london2012.com/settings/registration-confirmation.php) this is a global page used for loads of other purposes (it's not limited to travel users).

Secondly these pages are based on templates and so we'll need to add the tags to the templates (not the pages), this means we'll have to add in hard coded rules about which tags to display depending on the url / path / filename and if the pages get renamed or moved for any reason then the tags will break. In this case that is unlikely to happen (I think that section is fairly set in stone) but in other cases it may be an issue.

In terms of the links, I think we added these in as well? If not all those links are editable in the CMS so you can just add them in (although as they all have adfarm.mediplex.com urls they will be seen by the CMS as external pages and hence may get 'external link' icons - this is done deep down in the publication layer and isn't easy to change).

subject: Interactive map and audio on Learning Legacy site
description:
Add audio files (mp3) and an interactive map? 
 
Example: http://www.framearch.co.uk/t5/interactive-map/
 
One of the themes on the site will be archaeology and this section will be slightly different, with a few more pages. It would be great to know if we would have the capabilities of audio and using an interactive map.

Kitsite response:

In terms of the mp3 if they are under <10MB you can upload them yourself (as you would a PDF) if they are larger than that then we would FTP them direct to the web server for you. Will you be regularly updating mp3's or is this a one off?

In terms of the map, the main PageContent area is 460px wide so it probably makes sense to get any maps you commission built to fit that area. But I think we need some more details, are they Flash/Javascript/ is there just one map or multiple ones? does it need to be updated? Is there an accessible version of each map? etc. before we can give a firm quote on implementation costs.

For reference, see #4104

subject: postcode searching, Part 2
description:
See http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/1016

Jamie says: "The proper way is to do it is to add a lat/long to every event, you get this for free if you use the location picker in the CMS but not from user submitted events. Then when someone does a search we also turn the postcode they entered into a lat/long coordinate and then for each result returned use a bit of maths to work out the distance between the two points and therefore whether it falls within an acceptable radius."
